questions.text: A patient with ALL showing lymphoblasts in smear develops pain abdomen and decreased urine output. Workup shows increased potassium and increased uric acid levels. Next step in management is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydration The patient with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) presenting with pain in the abdomen and decreased urine output is suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). Decreased urine output, increased potassium, increased uric acid levels in an ALL patients, points to Tumor lysis syndrome. Acute tubular necrosis is a complication of TLS leading to oliguria. Immediate hydration is first line management in tumor lysis syndrome.

Highyeild:

Tumour lysis syndrome Most often seen with lymphomas and/or leukaemia. Cause: Treatment initiation or spontaneously in fast-growing tumors Pathophysiology: Treatment: Aggressive hydration Allopurinol Rasburicase

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Probenecid: It has no role in immediate management of TLS Option C. Urgent Chemotherapy: It cannot be given in a picture of already decreased gfr in acute tubular necrosis. Option D. Ultrasound Abdomen: It may be done to look for Organomegaly but is not the next best step in management.

questions.text: A 4 yr boy is brought to hospital with complaints of frequent falls when he tries to run. He is also found to have difficulty in getting up from squatting. The muscle biopsy image is shown below. Which of the following is true about this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: It is a Post Viral Pathology

questions.correct_answer: B. Death usually occurs by 3rd Decade
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Death usually occurs by 3rd Decade The given clinical scenario with histopathological image showing muscle degeneration and muscle tissue replaced by connective tissue suggests the diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). True statement regarding DMD is B. Death usually occurs by 3rd Decade. It is a progressive muscle disease . Initially proximal muscles are involved, later distal muscles are involved. Respiratory muscles may get involved leading to eventual death.

Highyeild:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) It is an X-linked recessive disorder that primarily affects males. Cause: Mutation in the DMD gene, which codes for the protein dystrophin. Pathophysiology: Dystrophin is an important protein that helps maintain the structure and stability of muscle fibers. In DMD, the absence of dystrophin leads to progressive muscle weakness and wasting. Features: Symptoms appear in early childhood Difficulty walking, frequent falls, and muscle weakness in the hips, thighs, and shoulders. As the disease progresses, it can affect the heart and respiratory muscles, leading to life-threatening complications. Most boys with DMD lose the ability to walk by their teenage years and typically die in their 20s or 30s. Gower sign: Patient uses upper extremity to stand up Diagnosis : Increased CK and aldolase, genetic testing

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Excellent Prognosis if Detected Early: False. No definitive treatment is available. Hence early detection does not help in improving prognosis. Option C .It is a Post Viral Pathology:False.It is a progressive muscle disease caused by mutation in X chromosome leading to decreased production of dystrophin protein. Option D .Mitochondrial Inheritance:False. Inheritance of DMD is X linked recessive.

Extraedge:

Clinical features of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

questions.text: A middle aged female patient died of COVID 19, she was on a ventilator. Which of the following findings is seen in lung autopsy?

options.label: C
options.text: Acute and Chronic Hemorrhages in the Lung Tissue

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thick Fibrin Lining Alveoli The most common finding seen in lung autopsies of patients who have died from COVID-19 is ‘Thick Fibrin Lining Alveoli’. This fibrin is a result of widespread inflammation and damage to the lung tissue caused by the virus causing Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome.

Highyeild:

Histopathological findings of ARDS Hyaline membranes : These are pink-staining, proteinaceous deposits that form on the inner surface of the alveoli, and are the hallmark of ARDS. Hyaline membranes are formed due to the accumulation of plasma proteins and cellular debris in the alveoli, resulting in damage to the alveolar-capillary barrier. Inflammation : ARDS is characterized by an inflammatory response in the lungs, which is indicated by the presence of neutrophils and macrophages in the alveoli and interstitial spaces. Edema : The alveolar-capillary barrier in the lungs becomes leaky in ARDS, leading to the accumulation of fluid in the alveoli and interstitial spaces, which is known as pulmonary edema. Alveolar damage : The histopathological features of ARDS include damage to the alveolar walls, leading to the collapse of the alveoli and impaired gas exchange in the lungs. Fibrosis : In some cases of ARDS, there may be the development of fibrosis (scarring) in the lungs, which can lead to long-term respiratory problems. https://images.app.goo.gl/BbY2go5WsikXVKyr7

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Intra Cytoplasmic & Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies: This finding is not typically associated with COVID-19. Inclusion bodies are abnormal structures that can be seen in cells infected with certain viruses, but they are not a characteristic feature of COVID-19. Option C. Acute and Chronic Hemorrhages in the Lung Tissue: While some patients with severe COVID-19 may experience lung bleeding or hemorrhages, it is not a consistent finding in all cases. It is more commonly associated with other underlying conditions or complications. Option D. Edema: Pulmonary edema, which refers to the accumulation of fluid in the lung tissue, can occur in severe cases of COVID-19. However, it is not the most specific or characteristic finding in lung autopsies of COVID-19 patients.

Table:

#MANTRA Phases of ARDS Phase Duration Features Exudative Day 1-7 Alveolar damage, hyaline membrane formation, interstitial edema, alveolar flooding, and surfactant depletion Proliferative Day 7-21 Inflammatory cells, fibroblasts, and myofibroblasts migrate to the alveoli, leading to fibrosis and collagen deposition Fibrotic Beyond day 21 Fibrosis, scarring, and remodeling of the lung tissue, leading to irreversible lung damage and impaired gas exchange

questions.text: A patient presented with fatigue, microcytic hypochromic anemia with reduced RBC indices and target cells. Blood workup showed Hb-10 gm%, MCV 60, MCH-23, MCHC-27. RBC count is 5.2 x 109/μl and Mentzer Index is 10. What is the next investigation to be done for the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HbA2 Based on the provided information, the patient's presentation with microcytic hypochromic anemia , reduced RBC indices, target cells , and a Mentzer Index of 10 ( less than 13) suggests the possibility of thalassemia rather than iron deficiency anemia. In this case, the next investigation to be done for the diagnosis is HbA2 . Elevated levels of HbA2 are typically seen in beta-thalassemia , which is the most common type of thalassemia. Measurement of HbA2 levels through hemoglobin electrophoresis or high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) can help differentiate thalassemia from other causes of microcytic anemia

Highyeild:

Pathogenesis of Beta-Thalassemia Differential diagnosis of Microcytic anemia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Serum Ferritin:These levels are typically decreased in iron deficiency anemia, not thalassemia. Since the patient's presentation is more consistent with thalassemia, serum ferritin may not provide relevant diagnostic information in this context. Option C. Serum Folate: Folate deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia, which is characterized by macrocytic red blood cells. The patient's microcytic hypochromic anemia and reduced RBC indices make folate deficiency less likely as the underlying cause. Option D . Homocysteine: Elevated homocysteine levels are associated with vitamin B12 deficiency and folate deficiency, which can both cause macrocytic anemia. As mentioned earlier, the patient's presentation is more consistent with microcytic hypochromic anemia, making homocysteine less relevant in this scenario.

Extraedge:

Mentzer Index = MCV/RBC count in millions If, >13: Iron deficiency anemia is more likely If, <13: Beta thalassemia is more likely When the MCV is low, the patient with thalassemia minor is producing more red cells to compensate for the small red cell volume to reach a normal or near-normal hematocrit. In the patient with IDA and a comparably low MCV, the nutritional deficiency impairs erythropoiesis resulting in a lower RBC count.

questions.text: A 56 years old male came with dragging sensation in abdomen and on examination there was massive splenomegaly. Lab examination revealed high TLC, thrombocytosis. Peripheral smear was showing myelocytes, metamyelocytes, promyelocytes, and band forms of neutrophil as shown in below given image. Most likely which translocation it will have?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

t (9,22) The given case scenario with peculiar features such as elderly male with dragging sensation in abdomen, massive splenomegaly with high TLC, thrombocytosis and all stages of neutrophil seen on PBS is highly suggestive of CML. The most likely translocation present in CML is A.t(9,22)

Highyeild:

Chronic myelogenous leukaemia Defined by the Philadelphia chromosome (t[9;22], BCR-ABL) and myeloid stem cell proliferation Features of CML: Seen in elderly males: 65 years Massive spleen noted Dysregulated production of mature and maturing granulocytes (ex: Neutrophils, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, basophils) Diagnosis : CBC – Increase in TLC, platelet and RBC PBS – Basophilia, leukocytosis with massive shift to left Treatment: Responds to BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. t(8,24): This translocation is seen with Burkitt’s lymphoma. Option C . t(8,11): This translocation is associated with acute myeloid leukemia with mixed lineage (AML-M0 or AML-M5a), which typically presents with different morphological features and immunophenotype compared to the case described. Option D. t(4,11): This translocation is associated with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) with the MLL gene rearrangement, rather than CML.

Table:

#MANTRA CML phases: Stable, Accelerated and Blast phase CML phase WHO definition Chronic stable phase Blasts < 10% in peripheral blood and bone marrow Accelerated phase ● Blasts 10-19% of white blood cells (WBCs) in peripheral and/or nucleated bone marrow cells ● Peripheral blood myeloblasts and promyelocyte combined ≥30% ● Peripheral blood basophils ≥20% ● Persistent thrombocytopenia (< 100 × 10 9 /L) unrelated to therapy or persistent thrombocytosis (> 1000 × 10 9 /L) unresponsive to therapy ● Increasing WBC counts and spleen size unresponsive to therapy ● Additional clonal cytogenetic abnormalities in Philadelphia chromosome–positive cells Blast crisis ● Blasts ≥ 20% of peripheral blood WBCs or nucleated bone marrow cells ● Extramedullary blast proliferation ● Large foci or clusters of blasts on bone marrow biopsy

questions.text: A patient underwent cystoscopy which showed multiple yellow white plaque in bladder. HPE shows infiltration in the lamina propria layer as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malakoplakia Malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous disease of infectious etiology that is most frequently reported to occur in the genitourinary system. Malakoplakia is believed to result from the inadequate killing of bacteria by macrophages or monocytes that exhibit defective phagolysosomal activity. Partially digested bacteria accumulate in monocytes or macrophages and lead to the deposition of calcium and iron on residual bacterial glycolipid. The presence of the resulting basophilic inclusion structure, the Michaelis-GutmannA body, is pathognomonic for malakoplakia and can be seen in the image given. Patients typically present with a history of immunosuppression due to renal transplantation,diabetes mellitus, or lymphoma or a history of receiving long-term therapy with systemic corticosteroids. Close to one quarter of patients present with internal organ involvement, most commonly in the retroperitoneal area, the kidney, the bladder, or the colon. Please note that it rarely presents in patients with HIV infectionand AIDS, which may be because of the preservation of monocytic antimicrobial function in these patients. Lesions may present as erythematous papules, subcutaneous nodules, draining abscesses, ulcers, nonhealing surgical wounds, indurated plaque, or draining fistulas.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: IC or painful bladder syndrome is a chronic, often debilitating condition, which should not be confused with common cystitis, a bacterial infection of the bladder that is the most common type of urinary tract infection (UTI). Unlike common cystitis, interstitial cystitis is not caused by bacteria, nor does it respond to antibiotics. Option C: In most cases bacteria ascends from the urethra to the bladder (cystitis). Bacterial organisms can further ascend through the ureter and infect the kidney causing pyelonephritis. It is important to distinguish between uncomplicated and complicated UTI Uncomplicated UTI: this describes acute cystitis or pyelonephritis in outpatient women who are not pregnant and do not have anatomic abnormalities or instrumentation within the urinary tract Complicated UTI: this describes UTI that is not uncomplicated

questions.text: A 30 years old patient is investigated for infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. Biopsy image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sertoli Cell only Tumor The given clinical scenario of primary infertility and histopathological image showing markedly thickened hyalinized basement membrane of seminiferous tubules with Sertoli cells along with no signs of spermatogenesis suggests the diagnosis of sertoli cell only tumour. It is aka Sertoli cell-only syndrome or Sertoli cell maturation arrest , and is a condition characterized by the absence or marked reduction of germ cells in the seminiferous tubules of the testes.

Highyeild:

Sertoli-cell-only (SCO) syndrome Also known as germ cell aplasia The testes are usually small to normal in size Testes in which only Sertoli cells line the seminiferous tubules No germ cells are seen which are involved in spermatogenesis Leydig cells are normally reduced or absent. Normal secondary male features Patients will have increased level of FSH https://images.app.goo.gl/Qn8cSuH28bbRija36

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Orchitis: It refers to inflammation of the testes, which may result in impaired sperm production, but the described biopsy findings do not indicate inflammatory changes. Option C. Testicular atrophy: It generally involves a reduction in the size of the testes and can have various causes, including hormonal imbalances, infections, or vascular issues. Option D. Non-seminomatous Germ Cell Tumors: It typically presents as testicular masses and may have heterogeneous histological features, including various types of germ cells.

questions.text: A patient with swelling in front of the neck came to the clinic. Complaints of fatigue. On examination hypothyroid and anemia are observed. Which is more common in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Macrocytic Anemia In a patient with swelling in front of the neck (goiter), hypothyroidism, and anemia , macrocytic anemia is more commonly observed. Macrocytic anemia occurs 20 times more frequently in patients with hypothyroidism and another anemia Macrocytosis is found in up to 55% with hypothyroidism.

Highyeild:

Macrocytic anemias MCV >100 fL

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. IDA: It (Iron Deficiency Anemia) is the most common cause of microcytic. Hypothyroidism causes reduced production of HCl leading to altered iron absorption leading to IDA but macrocyclic anemia is more common. Option C. Megaloblastic anemia: It is a type of vitamin deficiency anemia that happens when you don't get enough vitamin B12 and/or vitamin B9 (folate). Option D .Sickle cell anemia: It is a hemoglobinopathy caused by mutation of SCD gene on chromosome 11. It is characterized by the presence of abnormal hemoglobin and sickle-shaped red blood cells. It is not directly associated with goiter or hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 40 yr female presents with pallor and fatigue. She is a known case of hemorrhoids. Hemoglobin is low. Peripheral smea? shows the following histological finding. Diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Microcytic Hypochromic Anemia Given history and occurrence of hypochromic cells and pencil cells on PBS is diagnostic of a microcytic hypochromic anemia such as IDA (iron deficiency anemia). Iron deficiency anemia is a microcytic anemia that occurs when loss of iron exceeds intake It may occur with insufficient dietary intake of iron or in the setting of chronic blood loss (in this case from haemorrhoids)

Normocytic hypochromic: It refers to anemia with normal-sized but pale red blood cells and is often associated with chronic diseases or certain types of anemia of chronic inflammation. Option C.
